abstract.text: The ALICE experiment has been taking data since 2009, with proton and lead beams.
In this paper, the different particle identification techniques used by the experiment are briefly reviewed.
The current results on identified particle spectra in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV, and in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV are summarized.

In particular, the energy dependence of the spectral shapes and particle ratios in pp collisions is discussed and the results are compared to previous experiments and commonly used Monte Carlo models.
The baryon/meson ratio Λ/K 0 S is studied in Pb-Pb collisions as a function of transverse momentum and centrality, and it is compared to previous results.
The evolution of the particle spectra in Pb-Pb with collision centrality is compared to measurements at lower energies and discussed in the context of thermal and hydrodynamical models.

body_text.text: Introduction
The ALICE experiment has unique particle identification (PID) capabilities among the LHC experiments.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Nearly all known techniques are employed, allowing the experiment to identify a large variety of particles over an extended range in transverse momentum.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The measurement of identified particle spectra is a crucial ingredient in the understanding of heavy ion collisions, as it allows to access the thermal parameters of the system at freeze-out and it poses strict constraints on the (hydrodynamic) models aiming to describe the data.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The study of identified particles in pp collisions provides valuable reference spectra for the understanding of heavy ion data.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Moreover, pp results have their own genuine interest in the context of minimum bias physics, underlying event and the tuning of Monte Carlo generators.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this paper, we first review the PID detectors relevant to the present discussion (sec. 2).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: New results obtained in pp collisions at √ s = 7 TeV (sec.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 3) and Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV (sec.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 4) are then presented.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The results are finally summarized in sec. 5.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this work, we present particle ratios and spectra for primary particles, defined as prompt particles produced ‡ The full list of authors can be found at the end of this volume.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: in the collision and all decay products, except products from weak decays of strange particles.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Particle Identification in ALICE
The PID capabilities of the ALICE experiment are discussed in detail in [1,2,3].
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: In this section, we briefly review the detectors relevant for the present analyses.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: Particles are reconstructed close to the interaction point with the Inner Tracking System (ITS), which is composed of 6 layers of silicon detectors, utilizing different technologies.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: This detector can provide identification via the specific energy loss in 4 of the 6 layers.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: The ITS can also work as a standalone tracker, allowing the reconstruction of low p t tracks, which do not have enough momentum to reach the outer trackers.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: This option makes the identification of π, K, p ("stable hadrons") possible down to 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 GeV/c respectively.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: The ITS is followed by a large volume Time Projection Chamber (TPC), the main tracking device in the experiment.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: The tracks reconstructed in the TPC can be combined with the information from the ITS to form "global tracks", which provide better resolution in the distance of closest approach to the vertex, and hence better separation of primary and secondary particles.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: This is the case of most analyses presented in this paper.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: The TPC can identify particles via the specific energy loss in the fill gas: up to 159 samples can be measured.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: Further outwards, the Time of Flight (TOF) detector measures the arrival time of the particles, allowing identification at higher p t than accessible with the TPC.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: The total time resolution is determined by the intrinsic time resolution of the TOF detector and by the start time resolution.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: The latter depends on the multiplicity of the event, and hence on the colliding system.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: The total resolution is about 85 ps in Pb-Pb and 120 ps in pp collisions.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: Particles can also be identified in ALICE with topological identification or invariant mass fits.
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: This is the case for weak decays, resonances and decaying kaons ("kinks").
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: In those studies, the PID detectors can be used to improve the signal over background ratio, without any loss of the actual signal, by means of "compatibility cuts" with the  PID signal (e.g. requiring that the dE/dx signals of the kaons in a φ → KK candidate are within 3 standard deviations from the expected average value).
body_text.section: Particle Identification in ALICE

body_text.text: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV
In this section we present new results for π, K, p, resonances and cascades measured in pp collisions at √ s = 7 TeV.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The data are compared to existing measurements at lower energy, in particular published ALICE results at √ s = 900 GeV [4,5].
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The stable hadrons were measured combining the techniques and detectors described in sec. 2.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: More details can be found in [6].
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: In Fig. 1 we show the ratios K/π and p/π as a function of energy.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: As it can be seen, the K/π ratio is rather independent of energy, at least starting from RHIC energies ( √ s = 200 GeV), despite the large increase in the center of mass energy.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The p/π ratio is shown for separate charges in the right panel.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The difference between the two charges at lower energies reflects the baryon/antibaryon asymmetry, which essentially vanishes at LHC energies as already reported in [7], leading to a constant value of about 0.05 for the two energies measured by ALICE.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: Results for K * (892), φ(1020) and Ξ * (1530) production in pp collisions at √ s = 7 TeV were reported at this conference [8,9].
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: We would like to stress here that most of the ratios are seen to be constant over a wide energy range, in line with the above observation about the K/π ratio.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The multi-strange baryons Ξ and Ω were measured via topological identification of the decays channels Ξ → Λ + π → p + π + π and Ω → Λ + K → p + π + K. In particular, this is the first measurement of the Ω at the LHC [10].
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The spectra are compared to recent tunes of the Pythia event generator [11,12,13] in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: They significantly under-predict the data, by a factor of about 10 in the measured range for the Ω.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The shape of the p t spectra is also not reproduced.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: This is a general feature of all strange  particles, and can provide valuable input for the tuning of strange particle production in the Monte Carlo generators.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: In the right panel of Fig. 2, we show the √ s dependence of the mean p t and of the dN/dy, compared to previous measurements [14,15] and to the Monte Carlo models.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The spectra become harder with increasing √ s and the p t of the Ω is significantly larger than that of the Ξ.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The p t and yield of the Ξ measured at 7 TeV by ALICE and CMS are seen to be in agreement.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: For the yield, one has to bear in mind that the CMS result is normalized to non-single-diffractive events (NSD), while the ALICE results are normalized to inelastic collisions, and there is an overall ∼ 20% difference between the two classes [16].
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The statistical hadronization model was successfully used in the past to describe pp collisions at lower energies [17,18].
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The same kind of analysis was performed on the pp results at 900 GeV [19], as shown in Fig. 3, where the ratios are fitted with the THERMUS model [20].
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The thermal model yields a poor description of the data.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: The new 7 TeV results are also shown: the ratios are not changing between the two energies, leading to an equally poor description.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: On the other hand, comparing the data with predictions for LHC energies [18,21], it can be seen that most of the ratios (except those involving protons) agree with the predictions within ∼ 20%.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: In particular, the yields for multi-strange baryons is much closer to the predictions of the thermal model than to the Pythia tunes.
body_text.section: Results in pp collisions at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV

body_text.text: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

In this section we address a few aspects of identified particle production in Pb-Pb collisions: the baryon meson anomaly through the Λ/K 0 S ratio, and the kinetic and chemical properties of the system through identified spectra of π/K/p.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The baryon/meson ratio in heavy ion collisions was seen at RHIC to be enhanced with respect to pp collisions [22].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The enhancement becomes stronger with increasing centrality.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: It features a maximum at intermediate p t ≃ 2.5 GeV/c, which is pushed towards larger p t at higher centralities.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: These observations were understood in some models as a consequence of quark recombination (or "coalescence") [23,24]: in heavy ion collisions a quark can hadronize by picking up another quark from the medium.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: This increases the probability of forming a baryon at intermediate p t , relative to mesons.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The shift of the maximum towards higher p t is interpreted in this language as a consequence of the larger radial flow for more central collisions.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The ALICE measurement of the Λ/K 0 S ratio is shown in the left panel of Fig. 4 for different centrality bins [25].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The ratio is enhanced with respect to pp collisions also at the LHC.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: When compared to RHIC results, the enhancement is observed to be slightly larger, with a maximum shifted to larger p t as depicted in the right panel of Fig. 4.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The enhancement is also observed to decrease less rapidly with p t , being still a factor ∼ 2 higher than at RHIC for p t ≃ 6 GeV/c [25].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The dramatic shift of baryon enhancement, of order 1-2 GeV, predicted by some models [26] for LHC energies is not seen.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: All the particle/antiparticle ratios are consistent with a value of one at the LHC, so we focus on negative spectra below.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The spectra of π, K and p were measured using a combined ITS, TPC and TOF analysis, similar to what was done in pp (see also sec. 3).
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The spectra in the 0-5% most central collisions are compared to previous results at √ s NN = 200 GeV [27,28] in the left panel of Fig. 5.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: In order to extend the p t range for kaons, the K 0 S spectra are also shown on the same plot.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The π and p curves cross at p t ≃ 3 GeV/c, similar to what was observed in the Λ/K 0 S ratio.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The ALICE results refer to primary particles as defined in the introduction, i.e. feed-down from weak decays are subtracted.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: At RHIC the situation is not always homogeneous: the (anti)protons from PHENIX are corrected for feed-down, while the ones from STAR are usually not.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: For this reason, only p from PHENIX are shown in Fig. 5.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: On the other hand, the π from PHENIX are not corrected for feed-down, but since this is a much smaller correction than in the case of (anti)protons, this data are also presented in the figure.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: A dramatic  Figure 5.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: Spectra in the 0-5% most central bin, compared to previous results at lower energy (left panel) and to the prediction from a hydrodynamical model (right panel).
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: change in shape is observed, with the spectra at the LHC being much flatter at low p t and harder, indicating a stronger radial flow.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: In the right panel, the data are also compared to a hydrodynamical prediction [29].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: While the model catches the gross features of the π − and K − distribution, it strongly disagrees with the measured p spectrum, both in shape and yield.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The difference in shape indicates a stronger radial flow in the data than expected from the model, which could be partially due to extra flow built up in the hadronic phase [30].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: A similar disagreement was seen when comparing the v 2 of protons to the same model [31].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The difference in yield can be ascribed to the fact that the model uses yields from a thermal model with T = 165 MeV, and this is found not to agree with our data (see below).
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: In order to quantify the freeze-out parameters at √ s NN = 7 TeV, we performed a combined fit of our spectra with the blast wave function [32].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: π, K, p spectra were fitted in the ranges 0.3 -1 GeV/c, 0.2 -1.5 GeV/c, 0.3 -3 GeV/c respectively, as the π at low p t are known to have a large contribution from resonance decays, while at high p t a hard contribution (not expected to be described by the blast wave) may set in.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: It should be noticed that the value of the T f o parameter extracted from the fit is sensitive to the fit range used for the pions, because of the feed-down from resonances.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: This effect will be studied in detail in the future.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The results for the different centrality bins are compared in Fig. 6 with similar fits made by the STAR collaboration [33].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: We observe a ∼10% higher radial flow for most central collisions at the LHC.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The p t -integrated K − /π − andp/π − ratios as a function of dN ch /dη are compared in Fig. 7 to RHIC ratios and to our pp measurement.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The K − /π − follows nicely the trend from lower energies.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: Thep/π − ratio is similar to previous measurements by PHENIX and BRAHMS, which used a similar feed-down correction.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: Thep/π − ratio measured by STAR is higher by a factor ∼ 1.5, partially due to the fact that the p from STAR are not corrected for feed-down.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: However, even when the feed-down correction at STAR is taken into account, some disagreement between the RHIC experiments persists, as it is apparent from the thermal analyses of the RHIC data (see e.g. [34]).
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The observed p/π − ratio at the LHC is much lower than expected from thermal model analyses which, based on lower energy data, used the values T ≃ 160 − 170 MeV and µ b ≃ 1 MeV at the LHC, leading top/π − ≃ 0.07 − 0.09 [35,36].
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: The K − /π − ratio, on the other hand, is in line with the expectations from those analyses.
body_text.section: Results in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV

body_text.text: Conclusions
We presented new measurements of identified particles made with the ALICE detector in pp and Pb-Pb collisions at LHC energies, which demonstrate the excellent PID capabilities of the experiment.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: In pp collisions, the results at √ s = 900 GeV and 7 TeV show that most particle ratios are independent of energy in the TeV energy region.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: In Pb-Pb collisions, the spectral shapes show stronger radial flow than at RHIC (about 10% higher β t according to blast wave fits).
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The baryon/meson anomaly was investigated with the Λ/K 0 S ratio, and the enhancement is slightly higher and pushed towards higher p t than at RHIC.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The ratio p/π is found to be about 0.05 both in pp and Pb-Pb collisions.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: This value is difficult to understand in a thermal model with T = 160 − 170 MeV.
body_text.section: Conclusions
